Had to chime in on this one. "AMENDMENT II: A well regulated militia, being 
necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep 
and bear arms, shall not be infringed. "

This means that for the guarantee of a free people, we MUST be able to 
maintain our own power to fight the tyranny and or chaos that can be. As 
written, a free state is one that is NOT a police state. Requiring us as 
citizens to be able to form and be formed into a well regulated militia 
that each free state maintains. 

In today's wording the 2nd Amendment reads kind of like this. "Since we 
need to have a competent militia that is available nationwide to defend us 
in case of an immediate crisis, everyone needs to have the right to keep 
and train with weapons so they may join in that militia effort if needed."

If the agency of government has more power than the people via strength, 
there is nothing left for us here. They have already figured out how to 
take our earnings and spend it on policy, so that our vote no longer 
counts. They should really just make a new amendment, that would be the 
final straw. America would crumble the moment the first suit tried to take 
the first weapon.

A Militia in the day and age of the Founding Fathers was expected to be 
maintained by every single community. As such, every Militia was made up of 
all the able bodied men of fighting age and all men of the community were 
expected to be ready to come to the defense of their community against a 
domestic or foreign threat under the leadership of the local Militia 
Commander (whether that be the Capt of the Guard, the Local Mayor, the 
local Magistrate or another designated person). 

IN those days the entirety of the male population was EXPECTED to be 
trained in the use of their weapon and that training was intended to make 
them competent enough in a combat situation. In no manner, shape or form 
were the Founders suggesting that the citizenry should be armed without the 
guiding practice of firm regimentation and training. 

In the context of our modern world in which we no longer have militias 
because of the fact that instead of militias we now have a full time police 
force for our communities to act as a deterrent to moderate threats and the 
national Guard to act as a deterrent to more significant threats.

*Let a regular army, fully equal to the resources of the country, be 
formed; and let it be entirely at the devotion of the federal government; 
still it would not be going too far to say, that the State governments, 
with the people on their side, would be able to repel the danger. The 
highest number to which, according to the best computation, a standing army 
can be carried in any country, does not exceed one hundredth part of the 
whole number of souls; or one twenty-fifth part of the number able to bear 
arms. This proportion would not yield, in the United States, an army of 
more than twenty-five or thirty thousand men. To these would be opposed a 
militia amounting to near half a million of citizens with arms in their 
hands, officered by men chosen from among themselves, fighting for their 
common liberties, and united and conducted by governments possessing their 
affections and confidence. It may well be doubted, whether a militia thus 
circumstanced could ever be conquered by such a proportion of regular 
troops. Those who are best acquainted with the last successful resistance 
of this country against the British arms, will be most inclined to deny the 
possibility of it. Besides the advantage of being armed, which the 
Americans possess over the people of almost every other nation, the 
existence of subordinate governments, to which the people are attached, and 
by which the militia officers are appointed, forms a barrier against the 
enterprises of ambition, more insurmountable than any which a simple 
government of any form can admit of. Notwithstanding the military 
establishments in the several kingdoms of Europe, which are carried as far 
as the public resources will bear, the governments are afraid to trust the 
people with arms. And it is not certain, that with this aid alone they 
would not be able to shake off their yokes. But were the people to possess 
the additional advantages of local governments chosen by themselves, who 
could collect the national will and direct the national force, and of 
officers appointed out of the militia, by these governments, and attached 
both to them and to the militia, it may be affirmed with the greatest 
assurance, that the throne of every tyranny in Europe would be speedily 
overturned in spite of the legions which surround it. Let us not insult the 
free and gallant citizens of America with the suspicion, that they would be 
less able to defend the rights of which they would be in actual possession, 
than the debased subjects of arbitrary power would be to rescue theirs from 
the hands of their oppressors. Let us rather no longer insult them with the 
supposition that they can ever reduce themselves to the necessity of making 
the experiment, by a blind and tame submission to the long train of 
insidious measures which must precede and produce it.*
-- James Madison, Federalist #46﻿

definition excluding anything other than a 'well regulated' militia... 
which includes just any nondescript militia, an unorganised militia or 
anything other than a well regulated one. A population of individuals

As expected, he's totally missing the entire point of the 2nd Amendment. 
Read the Founding Fathers, they say OVER AND OVER the right to bear arms is 
an individual right. Period. The wording of the 2nd Amendment is also very 
precise. Frame it as follows: What? Why? How? What? "A well-regulated 
militia". Why? "being necessary to the security of a free state". How? "the 
right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed". There 
was no national army at that time, so it has nothing to do with "military". 
The militias were made up of the citizenry, and would assemble at times of 
threat. To have a well-regulated militia to secure a free state, the PEOPLE 
HAD TO HAVE ARMS. The expectation was they would be able to arm themselves, 
have some proficiency in those arms, and assembly to combat threats. Not 
just personal guns, either. The Constitution doesn't limit it to handguns 
or firearms. The gov't has no constitutional authority to infringe upon 
this right AT ALL.﻿

From Wikipedia ......A militia /mɨˈlɪʃə/[1] generally is an army or other 
fighting force that is composed of non-professional fighters; citizens of a 
nation or subjects of a state or government that can be called upon to 
enter a combat situation, as opposed to a professional force of regular, 
full-time military personnel, or historically, members of the fighting 
nobility class (e.g., knights or samurai). It was common for militias to 
engage guerrilla warfare or defense instead of attacking.

From Wikipedia......Local militias were formed from the earliest English 
colonization of the Americas in 1607. The first colony-wide militia was 
formed by Massachusetts in 1636 by merging small older local units, and 
several National Guard units can be traced back to this militia. The 
various colonial militias became state militias when the United States 
became independent. The title "National Guard" was used from 1824 by some 
New York State militia units, named after the French National Guard in 
honor of the Marquis de Lafayette. "National Guard" became a standard 
nationwide militia title in 1903, and specifically indicated reserve forces 
under mixed state and federal control from 1933.
From Wikipedia...........
The Second Amendment (Amendment II) to the United States Constitution 
protects the right of the people to keep and bear arms and was adopted on 
December 15, 1791, as part of the first ten amendments contained in the 
Bill of Rights.[1][2][3][4] The Supreme Court of the United States has 
ruled that the right belongs to individuals,[5][6] while also ruling that 
the right is not unlimited and does not prohibit all regulation of either 
firearms or similar devices.[7] State and local governments are limited to 
the same extent as the federal government from infringing this right per 
the incorporation of the Bill of Rights.
The Second Amendment was based partially on the right to keep and bear arms 
in English common-law and was influenced by the English Bill of Rights of 
1689. Sir William Blackstone described this right as an auxiliary right, 
supporting the natural rights of self-defense, resistance to oppression, 
and the civic duty to act in concert in defense of the state.

All Americans have the Right to Freedom of Speech. Some enjoy this. 
Others do not. Not everyone uses it. Not everyone wants to or feels 
compelled to. We also have the Right to Bear Arms. It's treated with 
largely the same respects as the aforementioned Freedom of Speech. Now, the 
people complaining about the Right to Bear Arms, could not complain about 
it if someone had taken their Right to Freedom of Speech. Since some people 
don't want to have to argue with others, should we shed our Freedom of 
Speech?

     Basically, people in America can have this debate because our Founding 
Fathers had the sense to realize that you don't just read the US 
Constitution Amendment by Amendment, it should to some degree perpetuate 
itself. We The People are in charge of protecting that document, so that it 
may protect us in turn. Sometimes another person is going to violate 
another person. The reasons can range widely. If you assume that in large, 
people as a whole are good and don't truly want to harm others, why then 
would anyone suggest disarming the good and law abiding citizens who've 
done nothing wrong should now yield their Right to Bear Arms because a few 
bad people misused their rights?

     This is why justice systems exist. However, it's rare that a policeman 
is just a few feet from your door when an armed assailant is breaking into, 
or has already broken into your home/car/business. Or muggers on the 
street. And so on. All of these people are either just rotten or they have 
mental illnesses. Sometimes they're the result of what happens to a good 
person when they are forced to take extraordinary means for their own 
survival in a nation that makes all law abiding, tax paying citizens 
purchase a variety of "tiered" medical insurance packages (if they don't 
have them already, or those within the poverty guidelines can qualify for 
free services (which I do admit is a step in the right direction)).

     This is the United States of America. And we most definitely have 
problems. And we most certainly will not get solutions from our current 
leadership. But all that aside, we do have our constitution. Both the 
document and as Americans. And all of us who love this country would stand 
to fight against any invader. I've noticed this fact explained before. As 
any invading force would have military, civil protection (police/etc.), 
militia(s), and citizens themselves (likely forming into militia's) if 
things got desperate. So simply from an overall safety standpoint, it's 
wise to arm the populous, even with modern weaponry and everything 
enhancing it being wielded by the military.

    Should the average person be allowed to purchase rifles, shotguns, 
machine guns, etc., if they're following the laws? Yes. Should I be able to 
say that? Yes. Should people be able to agree with me? Yes. Should people 
be able to disagree with me and generally make jokes about how I'm a 
gun-toting lunatic? Yes. Should they be able to carry guns? Yes. Do they 
have to? No. Do I have to carry my guns in public? Occasionally. Will I 
give up my right to have guns or allow them to be regulated if I'm 
following the law? No. Why not? I'm not a criminal. I've done nothing 
wrong. I've never turned my gun on another human being and I've never taken 
a human life. I do not deserve to be treated like a criminal while I've 
been following the law the entire time.

     So my fellow Americans, while I may not agree with what some of you 
have to say, and I know some of you won't agree with what I've said. If I 
had to use my gun (think severely extreme circumstances i.e. revolution) to 
protect your right to disagree with me and curse me out about it, I would 
do it. Even if you didn't appreciate it, I would do it. We all have to die 
some day, my friends. Some of us will die defending what we love. Some of 
us will die in comfort with loved ones. Some will die alone, and others 
still will simply go missing. We can't always choose how or why we die. But 
we can choose what we try to leave behind when we do die. I want to leave 
behind a nation my kids can grow up in and be happy in. I don't want them 
to "have" to carry guns, but I want them to be able to if they want or need 
to. I want my kids to live in a nation where they can challenge the system 
and stand for what they believe in, even if it's completely against my own 
beliefs. I'll be proud because they are voicing their opinions and ideas, 
and I'll know that there's an enormous number of people who have laid down 
their lives for them to be able to do that.

     The Constitution wasn't simply written to be read one amendment at a 
time. The Constitution was not written to be rigid and inflexible either, 
that's why amendments are possible. The Constitution and its amendments 
were not written just for our forefathers either. They were written for 
their children, and their children's children, right on down the line right 
up until now. And we, as Americans, have a duty to provide OUR children, 
and their children, their children's children, right on down the line as 
far as the Story of Humanity can go, with the liberties and the choices 
that we've been gifted. And they deserve to have the opportunity to do with 
them as they will. Because this is America. And "For the land and the home 
of the brave." just doesn't have the same ring to it.﻿

There has long been a background check requirement to buy small 
(concealable) firearms.  The mental health issue is clearly a problem, but 
because of right to privacy laws in the United States, a person's mental 
health status cannot be identified and will not be identifiable.  There's a 
question on applications regarding mental health (ie "Have you ever been 
involuntarily committed to a psychiatric facility or hospital due to mental 
illness").  If the applicant elects to lie and answer "no," no one can or 
will be able to do anything about it.

Piers Morgan says he wants licensing.  There is licensing in place (or at 
least registration, just like there is in the UK, by the way).  There have 
been numerous incidents of mentally ill and simply stupid people (like 
members of ISIS), who go about killing people with knives, clubs, gardening 
implements, and bombs - to name a few.  There's a popular expression that 
says "Guns don't kill people, people with guns kill people."  The fact 
remains that it's easier to kill with a gun that it is with other weapons 
(except explosives).  That said, look at the headline running beneath this 
conversation as the argumentative Morgan continues ranting.  It tells the 
story of a mentally ill young man who repeatedly stabbed his father - with 
a knife, then killed himself - with a knife.

method.  In the Sandy Hook and Colorado movie theater disasters, two 
mentally ill men go hold of weapons and used them to commit mass murder.

trained and licensed to carry concealed weapons, might the outcome have

Police Force, FBI, other law enforcement... all fall under this category.. 
they take orders from Government)

control)
